Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a spectrofluorometer for chemistry research and teaching
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemistry Major Research Instrumentation Program, Professor Warren De Bruyn from Chapman University and colleague Catherine Clark will acquire a benchtop spectrofluorometer with a built-in UV-VIS spectrophotometer which makes simultaneous fluorescence and absorbance measurements. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as studies of rates and mechanisms of photochemically driven processes and carbon cycling related to chromophoric dissolved organic matter (CDOM) in marsh, coastal and marine waters, e.g., processing and optical properties of CDOM in surface and pore waters in salt marshes, photochemical production of hydrogen peroxide in coastal waters and impacts on microbial water quality, production and decomposition of volatile organic carbon gases like acetone and photolysis of polyaromatic hydrocarbons in urban runoff.

A spectrofluorometer allows fluorescence parameters. In general, fluorescence is a form of luminescence in which light is emitted by a substance that has absorbed light or other electromagnetic radiation. Often the light that is emitted has a longer wavelength and thus less energy than the absorbed radiation. This phenomenon has many useful applications in chemical sensors, fluorescence labeling, dyes and biological detectors. This instrument will be used for research and also in educational activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We requested funds to purchase a Horiba Aqualog Benchtop Fluorometer designed for the optical characterization of CDOM in natural water samples in support of a number of ongoing research projects.  Optical characterization is based on absorbance measurements, absorbance based indices, fluorescence measurements and three dimensional excitation emission matrices. (EEM).  The Aqualog has spectral rates as fast as 80,000 nm/s allowing it to acquire EEMs up to a 100 times faster than any other instrument. It is also the only CCD-based benchtop fluorometer with a built-in UV-VIS spectrophotometer which makes simultaneous fluorescence and absorbance measurements, allowing for instantaneous inner filter corrections to be made in measurement of high concentration samples, eliminating the need for time consuming dilutions and post-measurement data manipulation.  Ongoing research projects that use optical properties to characterization the CDOM content of natural water samples include 1) studies aimed at understanding carbon cycling in Southern California salt marshes; and 2) studies aimed at measuring oxygenated hydrocarbon degradation rates in local seawater.  We originally anticipated working with four to six chemistry majors on this project. To date 12 undergraduate students have carried out research using the acquired instrument. 

 

1) Salt marshes are wetlands at the interface between terrestrial and marine ecosystems characterized by rooted vegetation in intertidal zones and subject to tidal forcing.  Given their unique landscape position in transitional zones, salt marshes are key transformers of carbon as it moves between adjacent terrestrial and marine ecosystems.  Salt marshes are known to sequester significant amounts of organic carbon in their soils as a result of an imbalance between carbon inputs from allochthonous sedimentation and net primary production by plants and algae and carbon outputs through microbial decomposition and carbon export. Carbon is exported and exchanged in the forms of dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC), particulate organic matter (POM), and dissolved organic matter (DOM).  While the magnitude and composition of exported carbon varies from marsh to marsh based on hydrology, ecosystem productivity and geomorphological setting, most North American Atlantic and Gulf Coast marshes have been shown to be significant exporters of DOM.  This marsh-derived DOM plays an important role in adjacent marine ecosystems where it serves as the base for microbial food webs, regulates photochemistry and light availability, and can mediate the availability of both nutrients and pollutants. Over the last three years we have used the Aqualog to measure the optical properties of surface waters and pore waters in local salt marshes.  

 

In general we obseved higher fluorescence and absorbances in pore vs. surface waters suggesting soil pore water is a reservoir of CDOM in these marshs. Protein-like fluorophores in pore waters at distinct depths corresponded to variations in sulfate depletion and Fe(II) concentrations from anaerobic microbial activity. These variations were supported by fluorescence indexes and are consistent with differences in molecular weight and aromaticity indicators from optical properties. Fluorescence indices are consistent with autochthonous material of aquatic origin in surface waters, with more terrestrial, humified allochthonous material in deeper pore waters. A PARAFAC model identified four components in the Talbert marsh pore waters.  These were: 1) a ubiquitous humic-like fluorophore with high molecular weight and aromaticity; 2) a more processed humic-like fluorophore with an abundance of quinones; 3) a humic-like fluorophore of terrestrial origin with an abundance of reduced semiquinones; and 4) a labile protein like fluorophore with low molecular weight and aromaticity.  

 

2) Over the last decade, there have been numerous attempts to inventory sources and analyze atmospheric budgets of oxygenated hydrocarbons. Although estimates have improved, significant discrepancies remain. In particular, the role of the oceans as a source or sink for oxygenated hydrocarbons is one of the largest sources of uncertainty in global models.  Budget estimates are limited by the very small database of ocean mixed layer measurements and a limited understanding of processes controlling levels in seawater. Over the last few years we have measured the chemical and biological degradation rate of acetone, acetaldehyde and ethanol at a number of local sites.  The primary site was the Santa Ana River mouth, a site which is constantly monitored by local agencies for water quality. Rates were measured for 4-6 month periods of time and were measured as a function of aerobic bacteria levels, salinity, temperature, pH, oxidation reduction potential, and dissolved oxygen content.   

 

Chemical degradation of acetone, acetaldehyde, and ethanol is negligible relative to biological degradation and in all cases biological degradation appears to follow first order kinetics.  Acetone, acetaldehyde and ethanol biological degradation rate constants ranged from 0.0002 min-1 to 0.0037, 0.0003 min-1 to 0.0054 min-1 , and 0.00043 min-1 to 0.021 min-1 respectively.  Ethanol is converted biologically to acetaldehyde with an effective branching ratio of 0.14±0.063.  For all species degradation rate constants were correlated with bacteria levels and increased in the wet rainy season.
